abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and institutional
            developments substantial. Lessons convey the following. By
            and large, within Africa, a Road Fund, financed from user
            fees is an important way to ensure the availability of funds
            for maintenance. In this case, even when the government
            lacked budgetary resources, the Road Fund continued to be
            funded. However, mobilizing local counterpart funding in
            rural areas for road maintenance is difficult, where the
            overhead costs for community mobilization (fees to NGOs) are
            high and are likely to make replicability difficult.
            Therefore, additional means of financing rural road
            maintenance should be considered. Moreover, when a Road Fund
            is introduced, the responsibility of each agency should be
            clearly outlined in order to avoid potential disagreements.
            Whereas the Road Fund did provide funds for civil works,
            conflicts arose concerning how the funds should be managed,
            and which agency should contract the work.  In addition,
            small and medium contractors (PMEs) encountered difficulties
            in the development of the new maintenance system; instead,
            it would have been useful to develop a system of assistance
            for PMEs during preparation. It is recommended to accompany
            the privatization of road maintenance activities, with
            widespread training programs, to quickly build up the
            necessary capacity in the construction industry.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Road Transport Project, an
            International Development Agency (IDA) project will address
            the most important priorities of the Road Sector Investment
            Program (RSIP) to complement and reinforce IDA s ongoing
            assistance to support Togo s economic recovery and sustained
            growth. Specifically, the project will support operations to
            a) rehabilitate and maintain both national and rural roads;
            b) provide regular and stable road maintenance financing
            from local resources; c) encourage private sector
            involvement in subsector development; d) improve road
            safety; and e) revitalize and strengthen the management
            capacity of transport sector institutions. The IDA Credit
            will finance works, goods, and services for four components:
            1) remedial maintenance or rehabilitation and regraveling of
            the paved road network, critical sections of the rural road
            network, and the most important sections of the national
            unpaved network to improve their condition to a level
            facilitating sustainable maintenance; 2) institutional
            strengthening of public sector management capacity to
            improve sector coordination, investment planning and
            monitoring, road maintenance programming and implementation,
            and to facilitate private sector involvement in transport
            and public works; 3) road safety improvement, including
            building and equipping a vehicle inspection center,
            technical assistance and studies, collection and analysis of
            traffic accident data, school and public road safety
            campaigns, and training instructors and examiners; and 4)
            building mechanisms for beneficiary and community
            participation in rural road management capacity.

repnme.cdata!:
Republique Togolaise - Programme sectoriel
            d'investissement routier : etude d'impact environnemental

abstracts.cdata!:
Togo's Road Sector Investment
            Project aims at rehabilitating the main roads and rural
            highway network, and setting the bases for its long-term
            maintenance. Mild environmental impacts are expected because
            no new roads will be opened up. Also, the project encourages
            labor intensive road maintenance activities that are more
            environmentally friendly. Field observations revealed that
            the project will have minor negative environmental impacts
            that can be mitigated. Dirt roads only require mild
            rehabilitation by resurfacing and eliminating critical
            points. Certain tracks of the tarred roads will require
            heavy rehabilitation in the short term. The needs of the
            rural population will be considered when selecting rural
            roads to be rehabilitated. Other minimizing measures in
            rural areas include: (1) technically restoring laterite
            quarries by leveling the grounds and spreading back organic
            soil on the area, and restoring vegetative cover through
            tree planting or grass propagation, or transforming these
            quarries into water reservoirs; (2) improving drainage
            infrastructure to restore original water transfers naturally
            regulating the wetlands; (3) improving the downstream
            portion of road drainage systems to prevent accelerated
            formation of gullies and erosion alongside and the roads;
            (4) Controlling dust, which can cause health hazards and
            mild damage to crops and vegetation, by frequent watering of
            construction sites, already widely practiced. In urban
            areas, mitigations include: (1) reconstructing and
            maintaining the drainage system, and paving instead of
            tarring roads to prevent urban flooding; and (2) installing
            vehicle pollution standards and an inspection system to
            reduce emissions. Habitat destruction and relocation of
            either rural residents or urban dwellers will generally be
            avoided, while recommendations for instituting a better
            compensation system are incorporated in this study.
